title: Portobello Hotel is a famous retreat for celebrity guests
text:
12 shares

Legend has it then-couple Johnny Depp and Kate Moss bathed in Champagne here (it’s a rumour that won’t die, even though he’s denied it).
Instead of going for a soak, rocker Alice Cooper let one of his boa constrictors loose.
And pop star Robbie Williams even tried to buy the circular bed after becoming one of the many celebrities to spend the night at London’s Portobello Hotel.
Surrounded by mirrors, the bathtub here may be one of the most famous in the world, but there are no sordid tales to tell after my overnight stay inside legendary Room 16 - unless you count watching football highlights as my skin wrinkled in the suds.
It’s better that I leave the wild fun to the actors, musicians and models who have been known to hole up at the boutique hotel for days.
Room 16 at The Portobello Hotel, in Notting Hill, London, has attained legendary status thanks to its celebrity guests
The room is small but stylish, featuring a circular bed (pictured), bay windows overlooking a private garden, and oversized oval mirrors
Actor Johnny Depp denied reports that he and supermodel Kate Moss had a Champagne bath while staying at The Portobello Hotel
Celebrity guests are part of the lure at The Portobello Hotel, where the small, stylish rooms have plenty of character and some rough edges.
Nestled on a quiet street in Notting Hill, the hotel is easy to miss, with the only marker being its name inscribed on the glass of its front door.

I arrived on a Saturday afternoon, with the hotel proving to be an immediate sanctuary from nearby Portobello Road Market and its tourist overload.
Setting foot in Room 16 is like taking a trip through time - not just because of its famous tales.
The bright room is decorated with antique fixtures and dark wood furniture, oversized oval mirrors, and a lovely peach-coloured loveseat, with a floral design, that you might find in someone’s gran’s house.
Open since 1971, The Portobello Hotel is set in two converted neo-classical mansions, and its 21 rooms feature individual designs
Despite its celebrity clientele, The Portobello Hotel is very laid back and not pretentious, and is set on a very quiet residential street
Nestled on a quiet street in Notting Hill,
But the room’s best features are its big three - the Victorian claw-foot bathtub with several nozzles that took a few minutes to master before a deep soak, an 8ft circular bed with curtains, and floor-to-ceiling bay windows overlooking a private garden guests don’t have access to.
A giant antique wardrobe near the door hides a mini bar, wash basin, kettle and Nespresso machine.
The cheerful room has its quirks and some details, such as the carpet and a noisy sink in the bathroom, could use an upgrade.
Despite its celebrity clientele, The Portobello Hotel is very laid back and not pretentious.
Open since 1971, the hotel is set in two converted neo-classical mansions, and its 21 rooms feature individual designs.
While it may not attract as many big names as it used to (the hotel appeared to be filled mostly with foreign tourists during my stay), it still manages to draw celebrities (a famous actor was sitting down for breakfast with his wife as I checked out).
The Portobello Hotel has five room categories - single, good, better, great (pictured, with a four poster bed) and exceptional
Better rooms, like this one, have a king-sized bed and an intimate feel with pitched ceilings, open baths and separate showers
In The Portobello Hotel's sitting room, guests can pour their favourite tipple at an honesty bar, or enjoy a continental breakfast
The boutique hotel is nestled on a quiet residential street, with the only marker being its name inscribed on the glass of its front door
Given its small footprint, the hotel doesn’t have its own restaurant, although there is a complimentary breakfast in the large sitting room, with offerings such as croissants, cheese, prosciutto, cereals, yoghurt and fruit juices.
A cooked breakfast menu, with everything from a couple of eggs to a full English, is available for an additional charge.
When breakfast isn’t being served, the sitting room, which probably has some stories of its own, boasts a well-stocked honesty bar with a light snack menu.
The walls inside Room 16 may not tell any tales about my stay, but it was far from dull.
And while I may not lead a thrilling life like a celebrity, I certainly can clean up like one.
TRAVEL FACTS Standard rooms at The Portobello Hotel cost from an average of £195 a night. Exceptional rooms from an average of £395 a night. Visit www.portobellohotel.com .
